text:
I have tried numerous ways to fix this problem, and I am stuck!
I've searched the bug db, and I can't find anything about it.
I've searched the web and can't find solutions to it, but have found others 
w/same issue.
I have tried shutting down all other processes except apache & apache still 
takes up 100% CPU.
I am using Windows XP Professional (2600).
I would really like to use Apache2, and haven't had this issue with earlier 
versions (1.3)... has anybody ran into this issue before???
creator: iq@atari.net

text:
Matt,

Are you aware of the following problem that is fixed in CVS, but not 2.0.44?

  *) Win32: Avoid busy wait (consuming all the CPU idle cycles) when
     all worker threads are busy.

The key thing here is that all of the worker threads become busy before the CPU
is pegged.  Is that possible in your situation?  

Cheers, Greg

text:
Please search the bug database for reports of problems with win32 software
firewalls.  Many of them are very broken.

Matt: feel free to reopen this report if you can reproduce the problem after
uninstalling all virus checkers and firewalls and installing 2.0.45.

creator: emmanuel_ae@yahoo.com
text:
On Win XP Pro its Mcafee Virusscan 7 (both home and pro editions) that cause 
the problem with or without the firewall installed. After uninstalling mcafee 
viruscan 7 and rebooting the problem disappears. 
However the problem excessive cpu usage does not occur with apache 1.3. I 
shifted to that and it seems to work fine. That may be a solution.
I did try to probe a bit into the differences between apache 1.3 and 2.0. 
2.0 has been written from scratch for windows.
Superficially the differences that i could see was that 1.3 does not have a 
tray monitor and has a much bigger conf file. 
However exiting the apache monitor also does not help.
It must be something about apache 2.0's bind code i guess. And i dont think 
asking mcafee to change their product will prove useful. It maybe easier to 
figure out whats causing the problem in apache 2.0 and fix it. 
Till then use apache 1.3

creator: nd@perlig.de
text:
Blaming Apache for other software's wrong usage of system libraries doesn't make
the report valid.

The difference between 1.3 and 2.0 is, that 2.0 makes actually use of winsock2
features, which will be broken by (for example) the mcaffee virusscanner. That's it.
